awd_titl_txt: CC* CRIA: The Eastern Regional Network
awd_abstract_narration:
This Eastern Regional Network (ERN) CI-Research Alignment project organizes six information-gathering events: four workshops and two All Hands Meetings. These events are aimed at building and sustaining regional partnerships that simplify multi-campus collaborations to advance the frontiers of research, pedagogy, and innovation. With a deeper understanding gained through the four workshops, augmented by wider discussions at the two All Hands meetings, the ERN is better positioned to ensure impact across broad institutional types, research disciplines and pedagogical approaches, and well versed in relevant technical and administrative challenges and opportunities.

Two workshops focus on learning from the Cryo-EM and Materials Discovery communities about their research workflows and their computational, storage, and network requirements. These workshops also cover data management plans, types of collaborations (national and international), and the pain points associated with sharing data and resources between institutions. A third workshop brings together university Vice Presidents of Research, Chief Information Officers, General Counsel, Institutional Review Board directors, and other ERN representatives to discuss the CI Sharing Policies needed to simplify sharing of data, infrastructure, and expertise between universities and across state lines. The final workshop, “Broadening the Reach,” includes researchers, educators, and senior administrators from under-represented colleges and universities, including MSIs, HSIs, and HBCUs. This workshop ensures that these institutions can develop strategic and attainable CI plans and successful, sustainable CC* funded initiatives that leverage the regional ERN collaboration.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Summary

In July 2020, the Ecosystem for Research Networking (ERN), formerly the Eastern Regional Network, launched outreach activities through this grant to include four workshops and two All Hands Meetings. These were aimed at building and sustaining partnerships and simplifying multi-campus collaborations to propel innovation and research across diverse scientific domains and included information gathering in preparation for an NSF Mid-Scale RI-1 implementation proposal. The program focused on the Cryo-EM and Materials Discovery research communities, with emphasis on smaller, midsized, and under-resourced colleges and universities, including MSIs, HSIs, and HBCU, while looking to make solutions applicable to a broad range of scientific domains.   During the award, ERN held ten workshops; three All Hands Meetings; participated in numerous presentations at local, regional, and national conferences; and produced several papers covering ERN outreach activities and collaborative projects. 

These activities provided forums for information collection, open discussions around cyberinfrastructure, and resource needs to advance the frontiers of research and education through enhanced collaboration and strategic initiatives. For science drivers, the discussions touched on research workflows; access to research instruments; computational, storage, and network requirements; data management plans; collaboration types; and pain points associated with sharing data and resources between institutions. For under-resourced and under-represented academic institutions, we targeted improving both our understanding of how best to support them and how to help them develop strategic and attainable CI plans that will ultimately lead to successful and sustainable CC* funded initiatives.  This included identifying workforce development resources, navigating federal funding opportunities, and preparing for advanced technologies. Also under consideration was what policies need to be in place that will simplify the sharing of data, infrastructure, and people's time between institutions, locally, regionally, or globally.

In response to the information collected, ERN explored a federated approach to resource sharing and data management plans, initiating the Structural Biology Remote Access of Edge Resources Initiative, Structural Biology Data CI Pilot Project, Materials Discovery Structured Database Initiative, Materials Discovery Remote Access Initiative, the Open Cyberinfrastructure Collaboratory Project (OpenCI Lab) and the CryoEM Remote Instrument Access Project. OpenCI provides standards, blueprints, policies, and training associated with the design and implementation of an infrastructure that democratizes access to research instruments and the data created by these instruments and was included in the ERN’s NSF Mid-Scale RI-1 and CSSI proposals. A pilot project, which involved CryoEM, became the result of the conversations out of the working groups associated with this project. Access to resources from this project are available on the website https://ern.ci and on the github repository of the CryoEM Project, https://github.com/mghpcc/SciEdge.

Intellectual Merit

Through a partnership of educational institutions, research facilities, regional network providers, Internet2, and commercial cloud providers, the ERN’s mission is to develop procedures, policies, and best practices that enable collaborative support for advanced research through layered and transparent access to shared data, computing facilities, novel network solutions, and federated services designed to support research projects located at and between partner sites. Through this CRIA, the ERN has identified unmet needs in computing, shared access to data / resources, networking, training, and infrastructure to support the vision and mission of the ERN, including sustainability, which has led the creation of a CI roadmap and partnering projects. The resulting research and education ecosystem will support a diverse set of science drivers and emergent educational opportunities and offer the research community simplified access to a broad range of collaborative multi-institutional resources that are not available on any one campus alone. ERN continues efforts towards a comprehensive, collaborative and competitive implementation proposal submissions. 

Broader Impacts

Through this CRIA, ERN has gained a deeper understanding of the needs and requirements to best support researchers, educators, and uppe administration from the research community, particularly smaller, mid-sized, and under-resourced colleges and universities. This knowledge has enabled the ERN to develop several science driver initiatives and the OpenCI Lab, which will have the broadest impact across multiple research disciplines, pedagogical approaches, senior level college and university administrators, and other organizations. OpenCI Lab will democratize research capacity and catalyze major scientific breakthroughs by dramatically reducing or eliminating barriers to accessing data, instrumentation, analysis tools, and specialized expertise and services in many scientific domains. It will provide a means for researchers and students of underrepresented minorities or under-resourced institutions to engage in cutting-edge research.
